title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act titled "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006" establishes the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established in the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, covering approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a final map and boundary description for the scenic area, which will be available for public inspection. The Secretary will manage the Mountaintown National Scenic Area to protect its scenic quality, water resources, and wildlife habitat. The map and boundary description will be available for public inspection to ensure accuracy and control any discrepancies. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area will be managed to protect its natural characteristics, water resources, vegetation for wildlife habitat, old-growth forest development, and recreation opportunities. Management purposes take precedence over general laws and regulations. A management plan must be developed within three years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must develop a management plan for the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within three years of the Act's enactment. No new roads can be built in the scenic area, except for access to private lands. No new roads can be constructed within the Mountaintown National Scenic Area, except for access to private lands. Timber harvest is prohibited, except for fire control and public safety. Motorized travel is not allowed, unless authorized by the Secretary for administrative purposes. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area prohibits new road construction and timber harvest, except for fire control and public safety. Motorized travel is generally not allowed, but may be authorized by the Secretary for administrative purposes. Within the scenic area, wildfires will be suppressed, insect and disease outbreaks controlled, and water quality maintained or enhanced. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area prohibits new road construction and timber harvest, except for fire control and public safety. Motorized travel is generally not allowed, but may be authorized by the Secretary for administrative purposes. The scenic area is administered to maintain or enhance existing water quality. Federally owned lands in the area are withdrawn from mining activities, subject to valid existing rights. Designation of additional national forest system land as wilderness in Georgia. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres of land in Georgia as wilderness, including additions to existing wilderness areas in Chattahoochee National Forest. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres of land in Georgia as wilderness, including additions to existing wilderness areas in Chattahoochee National Forest. The additions include Cedar Mountain, Duck Branch, Wilson Cove, Ellicott Rock Addition, Foster Branch, Ken Mountain, Helton Creek, and Tripp Branch. The total acreage of these additions ranges from 165 to 2,451 acres. The Secretary will provide maps and legal descriptions after the enactment of this Act. The Secretary will submit final maps and boundary descriptions of the newly designated Tripp Branch wilderness area to Congress. The lands will be administered in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this section. The Secretary will administer the designated wilderness lands in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this section, with no impact on Georgia's jurisdiction over fish and wildlife in the Chattahoochee National Forest. The Wilderness Act does not affect Georgia's jurisdiction over fish and wildlife in the Chattahoochee National Forest. Federal land designated as wilderness is withdrawn from various forms of use under public land and mining laws.
